newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek bourse to resume trade Wed, crisis averted.
newsitem.headline: Greek bourse to resume trade Wed, crisis averted.

text.p: The Athens bourse was expected to reopen on Wednesday for the first time in three days after angry stockbrokers accepted government proposals to overcome a fraud scandal involving at least one brokerage.
National Economy Minister Yannos Papandoniou intervened on Tuesday with a series of measures to placate the brokers after they accused the government of a cover-up in the brokerage fraud scandal.
They had refused to resume trading until action was taken to prevent a similar fraud in the future.

Panayotis Kondalexis, president of the 65-member Association of Athens Stock Exchange Members (SMEHA), told reporters after a brokers' meeting that Papandoniou's proposals were accepted and the decision to resume trading was unanimous.

"We believe the conditions for resuming operations at the Athens stock exchange are satisfied," he said. Brokerages may resume trading as soon as they settle their accounts at the clearing house. They should all be back trading by Thursday.

The sudden turnaround in the crisis came hours after the row blew up with SMEHA publicly denouncing the government's handling of the scandal and a state prosecutor laying negligence charges against unnamed stock exchange officials.

"We didn't get everything we wanted but it is a good step towards a more open market and putting an end to bad elements who have damaged the exchange," said Constantine Panagides, general director of Axon Securities.
He said Papandoniou's measures signalled the beginning of a rapid, thorough and unimpeachable examination of all brokerage transactions by independent international auditors.
"That it will not apply to clearing, as we had wanted, is unfortunate but the new measures are a big step in the right direction," he said.
The bourse crisis erupted last week when a state prosecutor brought fraud charges against one brokerage, Delta Securities. Delta's assets and accounts were frozen and offices sealed.

Delta's three top officials were charged with fraud after the firm tried to settle a 2.6 billion drachma ($11 million) account with the bourse clearing house with bad cheques. Delta has made no comment since the charges were brought.

Brokers seized on the Delta scandal to demand that the settlement system be investigated, with a look at brokerages on the other side of the Delta deals, to ensure the system was not abused to manipulate prices.
The government, smarting from the SMEHA charge of cover-up, ordered inspectors on Tuesday to audit 10 Athens brokerages.
Some SMEHA members have expressed suspicion about trades in the shares in textile firms Magrizos, Mills St. George and Parnassos.
Magrizos, whose shares have been linked to the Delta scandal, said its dramatic share rise and fall over the past year may have been part of a "trading game" but denied any involvement.
"It could be a trading game took place," David Magrizos, deputy managing director of Magrizos, told Reuters.
Magrizos shares rose from 201 drachmas to 1,365 over the past year before falling sharply since September and closing at 911 drachmas on November 7 when the bourse crisis struck.
The crisis intensified on Tuesday when the state tried to force a resumption of trading by ordering several state bank- owned brokerages to go back to work and trade.

With colleagues booing and shouting insults, the brokerages began executing a handful of trades just before the close. The general share index closed up 0.09 percent at 918.91 on turnover of 1.71 million drachmas.
The Delta scandal looks likely to continue for a while after a state prosecutor laid charges against unnamed bourse officials for negligence in connection with the Delta fraud scandal.

Prosecutor Anastassios Kanellopoulos, who laid fraud charges against Delta last week, laid the charges against unnamed bourse officials, empowering him to summon bourse officials to testify under oath.
